text: Inside this box is the smallest computer cluster I've ever seen.

Under here there's a RISC V network switch that's managed.
So from any node on here, you can actually manage this network switch and set up VLANs for your raspberry PIs.

And there's a very lightweight BMC for power, so that from this slot you can turn on or off all the other slots as well.

So the power limits are real.
This is hitting 60 watts with 6 compute module 5s running the StressNG matrix 0 which runs stress on all CPU cores.

The other thing I noticed was when I just ran it on five of them, it was still getting up there and they were reachable.

So you can see it throttled here.
So if you're gonna run compute module 5s, you probably should heed the warnings from Sipeed and run maybe four of them or maybe five of them.
Six of them I think is pushing it a little too far even with the USB C power supply.
Also something interesting I noticed when, when I'm just running these at idle, it goes down to 0.2 watts.
And I think that there's like a weird power factor thing with.
I'm just Going to cut myself off here.
I had never seen this kind of behavior before, and I assumed maybe the GAN charger was doing something weird with my power measurements.
But no, I actually discovered another feature of this board.
Redundant power supplies.
If you have POE and USB C plugged in at the same time, it'll fail over between the two.
And in my case, my other network cable was plugged into this other POE switch, but that switch is only giving like 30 watts max over poe plus.
And because of that, when the board needed more power than that, it automatically switched over to USB C, which was supplying the full 65 watts.
I've also noticed that after I shut these down, I have to reseat them if I bring back board power.
So I think there's a power issue with something in the firmware on maybe these carrier boards or something that causes that to happen.
That's probably something I can fix in firmware.
They said that CM4s also have some issues with that sometimes.
So another thing to keep in mind, this is idle with POE power 22 watts.

First, is the switch a managed switch?

How much power does it use?
I showed some of that in this video already, but just to give some numbers that idle all slots powered off.
Poe was 8 watts, USB C was 6 watts idle with 6 CM5s booted, Poe was 22 watts, USB C was 19 watts, but that went up and down a little bit over time.
Maximum with 6cm5s running stress NG, Poe was pulling 68 watts or so.
That was again with the power losses inherent in the actual adapter.
Same thing with the USB C, but it was pulling 60.8 watts with that same stress NG test.
How fast is networking all all the PIs were giving me a full gigabit individually, but that's of course bottlenecked quite a bit because there's just a 1 gigabit uplink.
So you know, if you need a lot of network bandwidth, this is not the board for you.
Can you run K3s or Kubernetes on it?
Yes.
In fact I ran my PI cluster Ansible Playbook and it installed Kubernetes with a Drupal web app running inside of it.
I can monitor the cluster with K9s.
I could see all the stats in Grafana dashboards.
Everything in there ran just fine like any other PI cluster I've set up.
How fast is it?
Well, running my HPL clustering benchmark, I got 112 gigaflops.
That's actually faster than a single M2 MacBook Air, at least the base model.
And it's faster than two N100 mini PCs put together.
But I have to add some caveats here.
First, I was running the four gig models and only four of them because that was the most stable configuration I could run with the power and thermal limits.
I could get more performance with 16 gig CM5s, but then the cluster would go from like 500 bucks all in to over $1,000.
Second, whether you can see that performance gain really depends on what you're running.
This thing doesn't just glue all the CPUs together, you have to run distributed software or have stuff running separately in each slot like blade servers.
Finally, Apple still takes the efficiency crown.
The PI isn't terrible, but it's really on the low end of ARM efficiency compared to like Apple and Rockchip.
It's more efficient than intel, but only a little.
I mean intel is a kind of a low bar to clear there.
I also ran distributed LLAMA on it and I could get 17 or so tokens per second with a small model using about 40 watts of power for four nodes.
It's not slow, but it's not a speed champ either compared to just like running a single computer with a GPU.
But what's cool is for 500 bucks you can have a learning platform for things like distributed LLMs or HPC high performance computing.
And that's I think where the niche is that this thing might make the most sense.
It's not like this is a practical option versus like a single server for a home lab.
But if you want to learn how clustering works or build software that scales horizontally, this takes up almost zero space and uses only 60 watts of power.
Stack up mini PCs and you'll burn through 100 watts in no time with similar cluster performance on the low end.
How fast does this compile the Linux kernel?
Well, I have a shirt for that.
First of all, go check out redshirtjeff.com, but I set up DIST so I could distribute a Linux kernel, recompile over four compute modules.
And normally a compile takes about 45 minutes on a single one.
So with four going at it, it didn't use all the available compute power, but it did get that compile time down to about 22 minutes.
So a little over two times faster with four nodes, which honestly for a cluster that's fine.
Will it ceph technically, yes, you can have distributed storage on a cluster like this with a bunch of NVMe drives, but one gigabit networking isn't the best for that.
If there were some bottlenecks on the kernel compile, there's going to be way more bottlenecks with a distributed file system running over that one gigabit network.
Do other compute modules work on it?
I don't know yet.
I have almost every other compute module board in existence, so I'll try to test a few when I get some time.

But these things take a lot of time, especially since, unlike with the Raspberry PI, a lot of these clone boards, they're just not well supported and I have enough trouble just testing them outside of a headless cluster environment.
What are some actual use cases for it?
If your needs are modest, a tiny multi node home lab for kubernetes or just running separate services on separate machines?
That might make sense here for a very small niche of people.

It's actually a nice compact setup for things like CI jobs or distributed compiles that run better on ARM CPUs natively, where you might not have the space or the budget for something like an ampere server.
Otherwise this thing's a fun learning platform.
Not everything in your home lab has to be the most practical thing in the world, otherwise there'd be no market for old Dell poweredge servers.
Can you run a full DOOM deathmatch on the cluster with each PI running as a different player?
Actually, you might be able to with PI Connect, but latency and the fun of the experience might not be there.
Can it play Crysis?
Well, there's actually a chance it could.

It has an M2 slot and I can adapt that to a full size PCIe slot and put a GPU on it, but it's far from the ideal platform for that, and I don't even want to spend the time to try that because I'd have to change everything about it.
In the end, I think you'll fall into one of two camps.
On the one side, it's a fun little cluster board, and it comes with some limitations, but you might be willing to overlook those because it's not that expensive.
On the other side, this is a completely impractical device with no use cases, and Raspberry PIs are overpriced garbage.

For that perspective, I'm not sure if I'll ever convince you that you can still have fun with things that aren't your version of ideal, but for the former Sipeed I think hit a nice spot between cheap and functional with this thing.
It's not perfect and you definitely have to tinker with things to get the right setup for power, performance and noise.
But but I'm happy to do that.
It let me play with software I never would have touched without using this thing, like Distributed Llama and Distcc.
Right now, like I said, it's on pre order, but it should be available soon for between 50 to 150 bucks, depending on where you live and what options you choose.
Until next time, I'm Jeff Geerling.
